>The fishing history of Douarnenez goes back at least to Gallo-Roman times when, as archeological finds demonstrate, fish were salted along the cliffs of Plomarc'h.
>In the late 18th century and the years before the French Revolution, sardines became the driving force for the local economy; the fishing industry was based on their harvest and, later, processing.
>By the beginning of the 20th century, there were huge fishing and canning activities at the port. The strikes in the 1920s in favour of better working conditions for the factory women or Penn Sardin were the main reason why Douarnenez became one of the first communist municipalities in France.
>Today, the canning trade continues, although most of the fish are brought in from other ports. Douarnenez is still a centre of boat building and repair work.

Right dickheads, you're gonna see some real proper English food in here. Gets a bad rep in the rest of the world but that's because the rest of the world are fucking idiots.

We start with the humble pork pie, invented in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, which is actually my home county. It's a hot water crust pastry case filled with dense, roughly cut pork and fat, and then a bit of pork jelly to fill in the edges where it meets the pastry. There's really nothing much else like a pork pie, other pies don't taste the same. There's also the 'gala pie' which is basically the same but with an egg in the middle (nothing to do with a scotch egg)

>>18842342
Next up we've got faggots. Not to be confused with OP, they're actually a meatball made from pork, offal, herbs (especially sage I think) and then its wrapped in caul fat, which as anyone with Wikipedia knows is the membrane that surrounds some organs. This one's also from the often-forgotten Midlands (which shouldn't fucking be forgotten. With the canals and industry here we fueled the industrial revolution). Don't knock it until you've tried it with thick gravy, peas and mash. Very hearty and warming, mum used to make these for me after football in the winter. They don't taste anything like normal meatballs either. Mr Brains is an ok brand if your butcher doesn't do them. They should though, bring 'em back!

I lived for some years with my grandparents and I started to hate beef because my grandma would overcook it; she just threw it in a pot with oil to deep-fry it to the point it would come out dry, tough and unsavory. The years passed and I would still avoid eating beef at all, even when I began cooking on my own. One day I bought a thin cut, read about how to season and cook it properly and I stopped having that problem. I still don't touch fancy cuts or thicker ones, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18840235
I make my own kimchi in pretty big batches a few times a year. I don't particularly like it just by itself, so I usually add it to things like bibimbap or tteokbokki, but a really fast way to cook it up is kimchi rice. add 1 part chopped kimchi to 3 parts cooked rice, assuming there's liquid in the can add all of that too. stir fry it, add soy sauce for salt and a little sesame oil. even better, you can start with some diced onion and add a bit of chopped bacon, and put a fried egg on top when you're done, or mix in a scrambled egg or two. if you have gochujang, which I'm assuming you don't based on not having had kimchi before, add a bit of that to the rice before you cook it. you can also finish it off with green onions, sesame seeds, seaweed, etc. or you might like it right out of the can.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18838287
Turkey is easy, just takes a bit of patience.

I use a compound herb butter stuffed under the skin, and then I baste every 30 minutes or so for the entire 3-5 hour cook time (depends on bird weight)

I usually cover mine in aluminum foil for the first 2-4 hours and then uncover it for the final hour or so for color and skin texture.

>>18838322
Turkey sandwich meat comes in loaves and is like... a giant unbreaded chicken nugget.

It's scrap meat that's been ground up and blended with chemical emulsifiers, water, salt, artificial and natural flavors and formed into a loaf shape.

It would actually be fairly difficult to recreate at home. You'd have to start by cooking an entire turkey and removing all of the good meat. Then you'd have to meticulously remove all of the shitty meat off the carcass; this is what you'd actually use. After purchasing and having shipped all the chemical preservatives, emulsifiers, artificial flavorings, and natural flavor concentrates, you'd have to blend everything up and pack it tightly together to cure for a while. After that you'd have a loaf of meat byproduct just like they sell at the grocery store; ready for slicing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18838541
If you've got good quality butter (Kerrygold or similar) and fresh herbs (thyme, sage, rosemary) making a compound butter is going to be good.
It's less impressive with dried herbs and store-brand butter.

I personally shove the butter under the skin of the breast. But I've also been told directly injecting the herb butter with a large syringe is better for getting the herb butter flavor deeper into the breast meat, but if you don't own a syringe for this, just stuffing the butter under the skin and basting frequently still gives good results.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18839927
>its not even cheap now.
They undercut every other grocery on almost every product, with similar or even better quality on generic brands. On name brands that they occasionally stock, it's hit or miss whether Aldi can undercut another grocery when the latter has a sale. Aldi's limited time products can also be pretty special in terms of price and availability. Currently in the U.S. they have jarred sour cherries at a price that's at least 5x better per pound than anywhere else, if anywhere else even carries them (most places only carry sour cherries frozen or fresh when in season, and for jarred they only appear as specialty cocktail cherries at a huge markup, hence 5x).

At the moment however it seems in my area that Trader Joes (same company) has Aldi beat in egg prices, probably because Aldi has yet to figure out its supply chains for the cage-free eggs legally mandated in several states.

On top of spaghetti,
All covered with cheese,
I lost my poor meatball,
When somebody sneezed.

It rolled off the table,
And on to the floor,
And then my poor meatball,
Rolled out of the door.

It rolled in the garden,
And under a bush,
And then my poor meatball,
Was nothing but mush.

The mush was as tasty
As tasty could be,
And then the next summer,
It grew into a tree.

The tree was all covered,
All covered with moss,
And on it grew meatballs,
And tomato sauce.

So if you eat spaghetti,
All covered with cheese,
Hold on to your meatball,
Whenever you sneeze.

>>18827079
>The name Champagne on a Cognac bottle refers to its origin, namely the growth area the grapes were grown in. There are six growth areas–or “terroirs”–in total, and the two that are considered to produce the finest eau-de-vie are named Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. These two premium terroirs have soil that compares to the soil of the Champagne region in Northern France. Hence the shared name.

>A Cognac is called a “Fine Champagne Cognac” when it contains a blend of eaux-de-vie from both Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. At least 50% of the blend have to be from the Grande Champagne. When the word Champagne is used on a Cognac, it will either be preceded by the word, Grande, Petite, or Fine. This simply denotes the terroir in which the grapes were grown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829472
I typically use a chefs knife; I score a line where I need the cap to separate from the bottle by gently running the blade around the circumference where the bottom of the bottle cap meets the glass, then I use the back of the knife to crack the wax. Don’t worry about damaging the cork, the cork itself is attached to a plastic cap and there’s no need to remove the wax from the cap. See picrel, that’s my 1982 Delord. I’m pretty OCD so I gun for a clean cut as pictured since I like my bottles looking nice. This takes experience though. The first time you do it you’re gonna be messy, so do it on a big empty table or kitchen top where you’ve got plenty of space so you can subsequently wipe all the chipped pieces of wax off with ease. Enjoy!

Most Armagnac is ABV’d @ 40% (you can get higher), and I’ve had some pretty solid whisky at 40% even though I generally lean a wee bit higher for my favourites. I just had my Delord with my partner and we both agree no cheese or mushroom in the nose, palate and finish, lol. Looking at my tasting notes though, this is what I wrote: nose: extremely grape-y, like sniffing a well packed bouquet of fruits and berries packed in a basket held together by UHU glue; palate: sweet, minty and clinical, hard to pinpoint individual flavours, there’s something synthetic about the flavour but in a way I very much enjoy, it just tastes super clean; finish: the synthetic part really comes out here, plasticky but damn it’s addictive (bits of the UHU glue nose come out here on your taste buds, and just like UHU glue, it’s god damn addictive). This definitely won’t be everyone’s cup of tea, but god damn am I always in a heightened state of zen whenever I take my shot from this bottle.

lol yeah. Laubade does that, there’s a cloth string a few mm wide under the wax which you can just pull to get the fucker off. The problem with Delord isn’t the lack of string though, it’s that the wax is like fucking porcelain i.e. really hard. My older bottles of Laubade had no string but even despite that the wax was super easy to peel off. I typically don’t ever leave a bottle open for more than three months so I don’t have an issue with ageing becoming a problem. I typically drink one shot a day with my significant other (we do have one or two breaks a week though), sometimes we share one shot, sometimes we have a shot each; so with my rule of four open bottles at once that pretty much guarantees each bottle will finished within three months. I devised this rule mostly because for whisky it can be very unpredictable how well a bottle ages, and in my experience it’s not uncommon for shit to go downhill fast once the bottle is about 50% empty with all that air mucking about inside. Funnily enough I find Armagnac holds much better than whisky; I once had a bottle open for over a year and I still thoroughly enjoyed it. But like my current Glenfiddich 15 VAT 03 that’s open, I can tell I’m enjoying it a wee bit less now that the bottle is down to its remainder 35%. Still solid, but not quite as phenomenal as when the cap first came off.

>>18833006
Kek. In my shithole (Singapore) alcohol is taxed at a fixed value per litre or alcohol, not percentage. The sheer irony is that this basically means our alcohol tax is a poor people’s tax more than anything because for cheaper shit you pay a higher percentage in tax (since the product is cheaper but the tax is fixed): thus the more expensive your liquor the more meaningless the tax becomes (you pay the same $ per litre regardless of whether you’re buying a 20$ piss wine or a 1000$ or fuck it 10000$ bottle of scotch). Beer is thus pretty damn costly here (we’re one of the most expensive countries to buy beer in), but once you go into the 3-figure range like I dunno a Dewar’s 32, it’s often cheaper here than in Europe.

>>18832487
If OP has dagnosed celiac, then that's that. There's a test, and it's final, and then the doctors put you on the diet. Then people started making gluten-free into a fad diet (along the same evolution of Atkins and other low-to-no-carb diets) and were claiming "Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity" or NCGS, which is a controversial phenomenon at best in the medical literature.

It's similar with keto, which is a legit diet that existed for decades as a treatment-of-last-resort for severe treatment-resistant epileptics (we're talking one step prior to cutting their brain in half here). Then, in the same line of genesis of low-carb diets from Atkins, it became reimagined for the general public as a fad diet, even though it has absolutely fuck all to do for the general population what its original intent was.

Arguably these medically-inspired fad diets have been a net good thing for society, as they have raised at least some bare minimal awareness for horrible diseases and the requirements some people need in daily life to live through them, and have made such requirements easier for those people to meet. And while the counterargument to that is that people cite gluten-free and keto pseudoscience to be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes, I'd argue that those people would be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes anyway. (The internet in general probably makes it worse, though).

Semantics and translation issues? Salsa literally just means sauce in Spanish, but typically refers to chunkier or thicker spicy chili sauces in the u.s., with the word hot sauce typically referring to bottled and more watery chili hot sauce. That being said, though in Spanish salsa can mean any sauce, it typically refers to hot chili sauces, which can be further specified by saying salsa picante.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18841630
Homemade nut butters should be refrigerated once opened, you can tell if they spoil by their smell.
Jams/Jellies should always be refrigerated once opened.
Ketchup and Mustard are a little tricky because of the acidity and salt, but they still go bad much faster at room temp. If you're going through it fast you can probably keep it out.
The weirdest one is that Mayonnaise is shelf stable, but no one believes the manufacturers. It is terrifically easy to contaminate though, which is why most people prefer to refrigerate it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Having another thread on this topic. There was a good bit of engagement but I was too inattentive (you can only imagine why) to keep up with the replies.

>Anyone have tips for bottle carbonation? my results are real hit or miss. I pour off all the fermented juice into a bucket with a spigot and dissolve 1tsp sugar per liter then bottle, shake, and cap. I leave to carbonate for minimum two weeks but i never get consistent results between batches. any insight would be appreciated
You may want to add more sugar. Consider adding enough to both backsweeten and carbonate. Some batches will carbonate more quickly than others. The current batch I poured straight from a carboy into a party bucket without conditioning has, after only two or three days, begun to carbonate very strongly, and with only a can of concentrate and a cup of sugar, much more so than a previous batch with much more sugar than that. It's all variable, just give it time. You may want to turn the bottles over to distribute the yeast as well, this might help them reach the sugar in the cider.

This is the current recipe I'm working with and can attest is delicious, especially when served on ice:
>gallon of apple juice
>1lb of sugar (11% ABV)
>1/2 tsp of pectic enzyme
>1/2 tsp of yeast energizer
>campden tablet 24 hours before adding (champagne) yeast or none if using old cake (much quicker ferment with old cake, reuse them!!)
>add full can of concentrate + 1 cup of sugar for backsweetening
>bottle or not (drink immediately after clearing)
>either cold crash or pasteurize after 2 weeks, test for carbonation

I went vegetarian for about a year on two different occasions, another time maybe half a year. sometimes I was vegan, not on purpose but I don't consume much dairy as it is and sometimes I'll go long stretches without it for no particular reason.
>how did it affect you
the biggest impact was that it got me out of the mentality that a meal isn't complete without a slab of meat, or that meat itself can be the entire meal, and with that I got rid of a lot of bad eating habits. it made dropping all the goyslop much easier. physically and mentally I don't think it changed me that much but I sit in a chair 16 hours a day, maybe I would have noticed changes if I was more active
>would I try it again
sure, though I don't feel much of a need to. when I went back to eating meat the amount I ate was relatively small and that hasn't changed. it's mostly salmon and pork belly, and very rarely is it the focus of the meal (like some canned salmon on a salad, a bit of pork belly to flavor beans for burritos, etc.)
>go-to meals
salad, fried rice, rice & bean burritos or bowls, japanese style vegetable curry, bibimbap, pasta, really a lot of stuff I ate before, just without meat.
>meal planning
for a little while just to see what I was missing out of curiosity, but after that I just ate what I wanted. it's not like I wasn't already missing a ton of stuff while I was still eating meat
>supplements
no
>cheaper
for me, yes, but if you're still married to meat and have to have fake chicken nuggets and fake burgers and all that shit then you will probably spend more.
>interpersonal relationships
no. I dated meat eaters as a vegetarian and vice versa when I ate meat. the only people who 'can't' date someone with a different diet are the ones who turn their diet into their personality.

I am vegetarian, becoming an italist.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
With you diet, you can think the way that your ancestors who ate a certain way did. Going back to the earliest man means eating raw, which I did. I felt so much better, I was never wrong and had such clarity of thought even though the ideas I got were so different from the mainstream that I was basically schizoposting in real life. Feel a "distortion" of this clarity whenever I eat meat and a dulling when I eat cheese. Going raw makes me need more sleep, I wake up early but I am asleep by 9pm.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
Impulse, just did what was easy. Converged on rice and beans with spices and no salt or oil (one batch for the whole week) before making the raw transition. Then I just ate carrots, fruit, and raw nuts.
>Did you need to take supplements?
I do not, goes against the whole thing the way I see it.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
If you are still going to cook, then yes. If you are eating raw, then no, grocery stores charge for nuts exactly like they are meat and veggies aren't cheap. This is a temperate zone problem only, though.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships? (Can't date a meat eater, couldn't eat out as much etc)
Old friends are sort of astonished and assume it takes some sort of discipline, which it doesn't after you stop making meat a daily habit. Family assumes that because of this, my not getting a booster shot, and smoking weed that I am no longer a good person. That is exagerrating, but it is hard not to view with suspicion people who view the burning of animal corpses as better and incomparable to burning a plant.

Only non-raw food I have now are some roasted nuts and also honey, which is not vegan. The seed oil may as well be cocaine to my system at this point, but I'm not gonna leave the nuts uneaten.

>>18836039
I sorta became a vegetarian inadvertently for about 8 months around the end of 2021. I was diagnosed with high blood pressure around that time as a mid 20s guy. It runs in the family but I was a fat fuck and I'm determined not to die an early death. I took a look at my diet and decided I needed to eat more vegetables and less processed junk.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
The first 2 weeks were hell. I was fatigued, hungry and consistently wanted food. I wasn't satisfied. I started to realize that a bit of hunger was good for you, particularly if you want to lose weight. I decided on one cheat meal a week, and let me tell you that fast food was the best thing I've ever eaten. I then realized that fast food was an actual addictive substance. That's what I mean by sorta vegetarian, I'd eat a meat meal once a week. After those first 2 weeks I felt pretty damn good.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
Varied as much as possible. Salads, MANY vegetable soups over a small amount of rice, as much fresh vegetables as I could. Spaghetti squash is a fucking miracle food, I still eat it regularly. I'd get protein from beans and peanut butter.
>Did you need to take supplements?
I took protein powder a few times a week.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
Hell yea it is. Potatoes, celery, onions and carrots are dirt cheap (potatoes less so now adays). Started my own garden with other shit as a complete noob and made more than what it cost me. I'm excited to start it again this year. Fresh and canned vegetables are dirt cheap, not so much in the winter.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships? (Can't date a meat eater, couldn't eat out as much etc)
The reason why I stopped is because I went to my best friend's wedding; I ate a massive ribeye steak and started puking my guts out, missing the after party. No one else had any issues.

posts.com:
Was a vegetarian during my most of my teenage years up until I was about 17. I was also a vegetarian for 49 days due to the death of my grandmother.
It takes about a week or two of getting used to, but after that, as long as you have resolve, you shouldn’t have any issues. You can still eat cheese and eggs unless you’re a vegan, so you really can have the vast majority of dishes by substituting. As I get older I would eventually like to go back to vegetarianism just for general religious reasons. I usually plan all my meals for the week when I go grocery shopping, and as long as you’re not a vegan you won’t need supplementation.
Good go to dishes: pasta, burrata salads, bruscheta, homemade nachos, mapo doufu, various noodle dishes, eggplant in garlic sauce, xifan, scrambled eggs, bean soups, potatoes, the world is your (vegetarian) oyster.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18835618
>Whiz is traditional
Except whiz wasn't invented when cheesesteaks were first made. Whiz was first added by Geno's to cater to Midwestern tourists who were dismayed that Pat's didn't serve theirs with the Whiz and Velveeta they were used to. After Geno's exploded in popularity with tourists, Pat's was forced to follow suit or go under. It got so bad for Pat's that all of their satellite locations had to close, leaving only the original one at 9th and Passyunk in South Philadelphia. They had a location on South Street, another on Ridge Ave in Roxborough/Manayunk and a third somewhere in Southwest Philadelphia (forgot where). The Ridge Ave location is sorta still open, but on Henry Ave and under different ownership, now called d'Alessandro's. The Ridge Ave location is actually where cheesesteak was first made in the late 1950s, several years before Whiz was even invented never mind sold in stores. Prior to that, it was just "steak sandwich" with no cheese.

>you'll get made fun of if you don't
No.

>>18835597
Any take away pizza joint in South Philly. If you're already close to Pat's/Geno's, J&J is about a block up 9th street from there and made decent cheesesteaks last time I was there over 15 years ago. Otherwise, don't go out of your way for one. Really, just about any place that isn't Pat's, Geno's, Oregon, Tony Luke's, Jim's or Phil's will be good.

>prov or whiz
Depends what you like. Whiz is for tourists and people from Northeast Philadelphia (IE tourists) and provolone is traditional while non-white people tend to prefer American cheese.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18835210
If you get charcoal just get a Weber kettle, the one with the fancy ash catcher is nice, but the cheaper one with the bullshit plate ash catcher does the job.

Go to Costco and get kingsford pro charcoal. You can usually get it on sale for 13-15 bucks for 40lbs. Also, just get the paraffin wax cubes to start the charcoal. Put it in a pyramid, walk away for 20 minutes and prep whatever you want and come back when the coals are ashed over and knock them down. Lighter fluid is awful and makes your food taste awful. Chimney starters work great, but you need welding gloves to pick one up that's started.

If you're interested in smoking meat as well as grilling, I would get a Pit Barrel. It's brainless to operate and the results are fantastic, plus you can use it as a grill.

I have an MHP Nat Gas grill which is great for basic grilling, and it's 30 years old, but they are also > 1000USD new. It's super convenient and I never run out of gas, but there's no satisfaction in using it.

Whatever you do, avoid buying chink shit from walmart or home depot, it will crap out within 18 months.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If this is your first grill go with propane. It's less work and you can control the heat more easily. Goes from cold to cooking temp in 5-10 minutes vs 30. Less cleanup, no ashes full of hot coals to deal with. Charcoal may have a slight edge when it comes to flavor but most of the time not worth the extra effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18841490
For Western Restaurants, good signs often are:
>Small menus
>Daily specials
>Never empty, even during slow hours
>Lack of a delivery app option(rare, but generally signifies the restaurant doesn't need the extra sales)
>Focuses on one cuisine type; Greek or Italian, not Greek and Italian, etc.
>Mentions in house preparation of things like fresh pasta, bread, etc. If they don't specifically say they made it in house, it's from a box and probably not very good(exception; high quality dried pasta is fine, but they probably aren't using it unless they are specifically mentioning it)

The menu for a Casual restaurant should fit on one double sided laminated sheet, in my opinion, excluding the drinks.

Bad Signs
>Empty Restaurant
>Ridiculously Large Menu, or too many different cuisines being repped

You can also check for certain very generic items on the appetizer menu. If their appy menu has like five or six things that you can buy frozen at the grocery store, it's because they get it frozen from their procurer. Beware of Jalapeno Poppers, Onion Rings, and Mozzarella sticks especially. All three is usually a sign of disaster unless the place is specifically known for their fried foods.

Finally, if the dessert menu doesn't specify they made it in house, or specify who the procurer is, that's another sign they aren't doing scratch prep. It's reasonable, especially for a small restaurant, to buy their desserts from a bakery/cakeshop and openly credit the specific bakery. If they aren't doing that or stating they make it in house, it's slop from a box.

For all Foreign Restaurants, if the restaurant is filled with the matching ethnicity, especially older people, it's a good sign.

>Indian
Should be showing off a great dining area and have no pizza/western options. Indians are very vain and tend to show off, good restaurants are usually well appointed.

>Sushi
Avoid Chinese run

>Chinese
Look for hand pulled noodles, hand made dumplings.

Broccoli is frustrating. Tenderstem is nice but boring, even steamed the construction of the typical floret means the buds will be mush and the stems hard, even when steamed, and even when steam dried. Never figured out how to make broccoli work without hiding it in something else. Any tips would be welcomed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18836289
>Steamed vegetables are just such a chore.
What? It takes almost no effort.

For hardy vegetables like broccoli, green beans, carrots, etc, I like to blanche them, and then saute. If you just straight saute broccoli its not going to have a nice texture.

Different vegetables require different amounts of cooking; if you want your veggies to taste the best you need to learn this stuff. For broccoli I would blanche in boiling water for 90 seconds, strain, use the same pan with some fat (butter or coconut oil) and saute on high heat. It's hard to say when it's done; you don't necessarily want browning. You want it to get as hot as possible without browning or burning. That blast of high heat will give so much good flavor.

If you ask me, cooking vegetables well is one of the most difficult things to do and describe. Luckily veggies are cheap. Try some stuff out!

dough is simple. you can either knead if you want (machines are useless if you're like me and like to have the dough for 10+ pizzas in your fridge) to be true to tradition or need exercise.

but you can also use the baguette trick the french do. add 10% of the flour or so to water, wait ~30m, then start adding the rest of the flour, the oil, salt and yeast and just make a high hydration dough you can put in the fridge.
i rarely knead and let the dough work itself, i take it out when i make pizza and add some flour while forming balls. the rest either gets turned into ready to use balls or back to the fridge.

posts.sub: How to deal with food hoarding.
posts.com:
My mum and dad just seem to hoard food in the fridge, and I don't know why.

It's gotten a point that our fridge won't close as things protrude out.
The seal around the fridge door broke and they paid somebody to fix it and put a new one and that broke too. They then bought a second one made me put it up instead of paying someone and now that's breaking too and has trouble closing.
They've broken away the covering of the light fixtures to fit in more food, they've removed the icecube tray and put food there, cold air doesn't even flow properly since there's no room for the air to move around and things melt as a result.

It's insane, like I don't think they even realise how bad it is.
I keep telling them too for years now, but my mum doesn't seem to care and my dad gets pissed that i bring this up. In fact they say it's the family's fault the fridge is acting up as people open and close it the wrong way, or the seal around the door was faulty twice and make up something to justify the fridge getting ruined and them hoarding food.

>>18834727
there are cheaper options, but personally first i'd grab some flour. i work with a similar budget. you can do all kinds of breads, pasta/noodles, pizza dough, steam buns, etc. get some sugar (and butter if you can afford it) and you can do all kinds of deserts now too. get some basic sauce ingredients and herbs/spices, add some meat, eggs, cheese and staples for sauces (canned san marzanos, parmesan, garlic, etc) and soups and you can basically do any italian/mediterranean or northern chinese dish on the cheap, it really opens up a lot of stuff and saves a ton.

with some medium/short grain rice and fish, you can really round out your repertoire. if i had an electric pressure cooker i'd buy more beans and stuff, but i don't really crave them that often. but when i do i love some chili with jalepeno cornbread. it'd also help with making stock/broth. i hope to start doing more thai food soon but this is basically how i eat, with the odd potato or meat pastry dish thrown in there. i also buy and dehydrate bananas on sale to eat banana chips.

I put about a quarter inch of water in the pan and cook the bacon in that. The bacon cooks nicely at 100C/212F without burning while the water boils off. This category of mistake is pretty typical desu. Baking powder vs baking soda (luckily many recipes explicitly require both), curry leaves vs curry powder, there's probably hundreds of common confusions for novices. Even very experienced home cooks will always be out of a required ingredient from time to time and wonder, "Why can't I substitute X for Y?" and occasionally have a catastrophic failure. (This happened to my parents on a substitution for a recipe that they had made literally hundreds of times since they were children. Fwiw I'd rather have my parents be experimenting and failing occasionally than insisting on running to the grocery, which may require driving, every time there's a minute ingredient missing.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bit of a cookalong for biryani masala, but with a twist. For background, a couple of months back an anon posted this picture to 4chan in a /ck/ thread saying this was the recipe for biryani masala that his restaurant used. I was really interested by the use of sandalwood and rose and such, and thought it might be fun to try myself. But starting to look into it I saw lots of recipes for “biryani” that used some very different spice blends. Of the ones I looked at, I decided I wanted to also try cooking one “authentic” version that used a type of Indian lichen called dagad phool, and one more basic recipe with spices you could typically pull off the shelf in a North American market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839945
That said, wanting to run these tests and finding which one I liked most, I wanted to set some boundaries and rules, to ensure that I was looking at each one objectively enough. First off is equipment, which is seen here, used for all the masala. Between the mixes I saw, I tried to quantify them out into mass where possible to scale appropriately and get around the same amount for each blend, which I more or less succeeded at.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839948
Some spices are powder, as that’s what was available/on-hand, but where whole spices are used I would toast them on medium low heat for 10 minutes, except for seeds and delicate spices which were toasted for 5 minutes at the same heat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839952
Spice mix pics. First is the 4chan recipe, scaled down (I think by 10x?). Its very eye catching with the orange sandalwood powder and the rose petals, and used a huge quantity of cardamom compared to the other blends. It also had the least variety of overall spices, I think.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839957
Second mix is the “authentic” version using stone flower (at 10 o’clock). The lichen isn’t remarkable as is, but once I started heating it up it smelt strongly of dried mushrooms and some other savory notes, which was nice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839961
Last one was the basic one, but this still had its own specialty ingredient which was the Kashmiri chilis (9 o’clock). Its also the only one using any turmeric, so the color was very noticeable. I really liked the smoky notes as this one as the chili toasted.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839966
Toasted spices were blitzed in a mechanical grinder to break them down, then run through a manual coffee grinder on the finest setting. I also had a mortar and pestle but wound up not using it. For those curious how well the coffee grinder worked, flower goes in…

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839970
... powder comes out. This probably isn't good for your manual coffee grinders, but oh well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839974
End of the blending, I had the following mixes done and ready to go. Obviously the basic mix (left hand) was the most eye catching cause of the turmeric, but the 4chan mix was also unique with the pinky tones. But I don’t know if I really equate biryani with pink, so we’ll see how the sandalwood colors it as it cooks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839977
I used chicken breasts, as breast meat is fairly uniform throughout with no strong taste. I wanted the focus to be on the spices. Breasts were marinated with 3 tbsp of plain Greek yogurt and 3 teaspoons of spice mix. I don't know if this is too much or too little, I was just trying to use best judgement. 2 breasts per biryani, as I didn’t want to make full dinner-sized servings three times over.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839985
Lastly for prep, biryani is, as I know, usually cooked with a par-boiled spiced rice. To do so, I rinsed some basmati until the running water was clear. I’m using around 1 cup of basmati per biryani, again scaled down to match the quantity of chicken. I seasoned the rice only with green cardamom, around 15 pods, as its the only whole spice I had on hand that is the same between all three masala blends, but adding whole cloves would have also been good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18839991
With everything set up, I’m just going to be cooking biryani for the rest of the time and posting pics every now and then with my findings, and maybe a bit more on the process.
Ask me any questions on my process, or talk about curry and stuff.

posts.com: as an aside, biryani is great, but I'm also a sucker for a good lentil curry or saag paneer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18840810
Ok, so closing thoughts on the mixes:
>4chan blend
Nice floral fragrance, delicate but refreshing taste, meshes well with the saffron and spiced rice. But the rose, used as powder and then cooked, might not be the best, and I think that if you want a rosey flourish, to finish it with rose water instead.
>dagad phool mix
Much earthier, lightly nutty, but felt like it falls a bit flat. I think the dagad phool added a bit of meaty taste to the chicken, but is the effort to scope it out worth it? In my opinion, not really, at least not for biryani.
>basic mix
This was comforting to smell, eat, and look at, though I probably have some bias as to the colors and scents. Typing this out, the heat from the Kashmiri has crept up the back of my tongue a bit more, but I still don't think its necessarily worth it as opposed to using basic lal mirch. Or you could use more Kashmiri.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18840843
So, which one do I like more? Its hard to compare, since they're all really different. Its less like asking "red licorice brand A vs. B" and more like asking "red or black licorice". Still, I'd rank it as:
>basic mix
>4chan mix
>dagad mix
If I were to make another mix from scratch, I would definitely pull the sandalwood powder from the 4chan mix. It had a super distinct aroma that I think kind of exemplifies biryani as being this "upper crust" kind of dish. I also have some more Kashmiri chilies, so while I don't think the blend I used had enough heat I don't know if thats really the chilies' fault.
That all might sound kind of wishy-washy, so if I can have a strong opinion on something its that the dagad phool didn't offer enough to elevate the spice blend it was used in, and wasn't very worth it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18840868
With every experiment, its good to point out flaws and where improvements could have been made.
As >>18840814 pointed out, I probably chose the wrong type of spice here. That really comes down to lack of knowledge on my part. Further, there are probably cooking techniques, just like in Asian cuisine, that if I knew of or was better at would probably help to elevate these dishes.
Pushing for each of these dishes to be judged on equal footing also placed restrictions on the mixes. By powdering all the spices used, it does potentially reduce the effectiveness of some of them. I know for myself the scent of freshly tempered spices beats out powders 8 times out of 10.
Cooking could also be altered. While I cooked my chicken breasts for 10 minutes after adding the parboiled rice, this could probably have been reduced to something like 7 or 8.
Further, outside of the spice mixes, the other constituents of the biryani could be handled a little differently to further improve the dish. For example, the spiced rice could certainly contain many more spices that would add to whole thing, considering how large a role rice has in the finished product.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18840919
The only thing you did 'wrong' is how you cooked the onions. In South Asian cooking onions are shallow-fried. You heat your oil to medium-high and then dump them in. You continue frying at medium-high until they become glassy. Turn down the heat to medium, stir frequently and cook until they're golden. This is also how to cook onions for curries. For biryani, they're usually taken a little further.

Go on YouTube and search for an Indian dish. Filter by most viewed. The top 10 videos will be in HIndi but you can follow them easily.

You don't actual want to caramelise onions in the layman's understanding of the word. Onions cooked this way become very sweet and, when used in a curry, become mucoid when simmered. And yes, frying them extra crispy for a biryani is a futile attempt to retain their crispiness after steaming.

First, I slit your throat, drain all the blood into a basin and make congealed boiled blood.
Second, disembowel. A nice, clean cut from middle of the chest downward, the guts should spill out splendidly. All the guts and organs are cleaned with heavy salt, starch and water. Special care for the intestines as they need to be turned inside out and cleaned, same for the stomach too. Organs are perfect for grilling, braising and stir fries.
Third, I chop, chop, and chop. Your brain shall make a fine soup, just like a pig's brain. Your arms, excellent for braising. Your belly? Too fatty, I will trim off the lean part to make meat loaf. The fat shall be rendered to make oil. All the muscles on the back? Slow smoke with hickory and maple. The ribs, I will chop them into pieces, marinate them, then steam on top of some thinly sliced mountain yam. The legs are for curing. Fingers, toes and neck, to make gelatinous soup. And the entire skeleton, exquisite, a nice golden brown broth.
Lastly, a feast shall be held for your family. They will eat you, and they will love it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Got a hankering for red beans and rice. Here are the ingredients:

3 medium yellow onions
4 stalks of celery
1 green bell pepper
6 cloves of garlic
1 lb dry red beans (I used kidney)
1 ham hock
1.5 lb andouille

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Typically you will use some oil to soften the vegetables. I made Alton Brown's beef stew last week and have some of the leftover flavored suet, so I used that. Got it hot in a big pot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Cut the sausage into pieces, half inch or so, and brown them. This will render some fat out too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: After ten minutes or so the sausage will be ready. Add the onion, celery, and garlic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: After the vegetables are softened, ten minutes or so, add water until it's covered by an inch or so. Add some creole seasoning, black pepper, a couple bay leaves. Traditionally you would add some pickled pork here (what the Louisiana folk call pickle meat), but I didn't have any as it's very regional. Recipe looked simple, next time I will make my own. This time I added a ham hock.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Forgot to mention to add the beans when you add the water. Bring it to a boil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: After it boils, drop the heat to medium and put the lid on. Cook for about two hours, or four if you didn't soak your beans (I didn't). Here it is after an hour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The beans will slowly break down and make the gravy more creamy. Here it is after a couple hours. I smashed some of the beans in the pot to make it even creamier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I cooked some Basmati rice with some of the suet from earlier in place of butter. At this point the beans had been going maybe four and a half hours. Remove the bay leaves, shred off whatever meat you can from the ham hock and add it back. Here's the end result. Tastes pretty good. Any Louisiana anons here? Does it look like the real thing?

>>18839314
There's nothing wrong with a book explaining how to make tomato soup. Nothing about tomatoes is self-evident: there are 10K-ish varieties, season starts half april and ends late september, they change through the season and year-to-year. They're a fruit with both sweet, sour, hearty and tangy notes - all of which change when you heat them at different temperatures for different lengths of time. You can make 100's of 1000's of different tomato soups without even looking at herbs, spices, mushrooms, fermentations and vegetable varieties that pair well with tomatoes. Far more tomato soup varieties than you'll ever get to taste before you die.

Either you stay with Failbook, Instagram, Pinterest, canned garbage and frozen pineapple or you go out and explore.

Kry to keto is not dumping a shit ton of money on rib eyes all the time. Whole chicken brined for 24 hours, air dry in fridge for 24 hours, then bake at 350 to 165-170. Multiple meals plus save all the bones and drippings for stock. Serve with simple steamed vegis that work for keto like broccoli, asparagus, or cauliflower. If you like you can also put shredded cheddar over them and bake to melt the cheese or wrap the asparagus in prosciutto if you don't care for their taste. Also learn to braise meat and then reduce the liquid for a gravy that is just made with the broth and butter/heavy cream at the end for thickness.

regular amount? blanch, squeeze a lil, wa-la
lots? blanch, ice bath (skip if making pastes or creams), strain and drop in batches into cotton kitchen towel (have more ready) and rub them aggressively between the towel, pour into bowl and fill with cold water to assist in clearing up remaining skins, strain or pick out almonds to final container, repeat

>>18840563
The recipe I use was from an old workplace. I scaled it down since the original made 5 cakes at once:

930 grams of cream cheese
250 grams of sugar
2 eggs
115 grams of whipping cream
15 grams of flavouring

1. Combine cream cheese and sugar amd beat for 20 minutes, scraping the bowl occasionally
2. Add eggs gradually and mix for another 5 minutes
3. Add cream and flavour and beat for another 5 minutes.
4. Pour into pre-cooked crust, wrap base with tinfoil. Put into deep dish, place in over, then add 1/2 of it with hot water.
5. Bake for 30 minutes at 300°, then drop the temp. and bake at 250° for about an hour. Turn off oven and let it sit while the oven cools down. Freeze overnight (cutting it semi-frozen is cleaner)

This is my first time making wine. Need some help from the experts on /ck/.

What order do I add potassium sorbate/ sparkelloid in? Which one first? If I put the stabilizer in first will it help get the data yeast filtered out when I ultimately filter it? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18840499
>What order do I add potassium sorbate/ sparkelloid in? Which one first?
I usually do it alphabetically; p comes before s, so potassium sorbate would go in first
but don't overthink this too much, it doesn’t really matter so long as your gravity remains stable

>If I put the stabilizer in first will it help get the data yeast filtered out when I ultimately filter it?
a coffee filter or old sock is going to be the best filter
pantyhose will work in a pinch too, but ymmv

>Is the stabilizer even necessary if I don't plan on adding more sugar?
absolutely, but you really should be pitching sugar at a ratio of 13:71 when you rack

>Only the one on the left is ready. Yes I checked the specific gravity and all the sugar is gone.
add moar sugar for greater gravity!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
All this talk about soup and I decided to make some myself just now. It's super easy. Just:

>boil 1 cup water
>mix (and mix it well) a tablespoon of the instant formula
>stir boiling water/mix into a swirl
>slowly pour in 1 beaten egg and then immediately turn off heat and "make ribbons" with your soup spoon by just gently running it through the egg you just poured in
>pour in as much soy sauce as you'd like, and serve.

That's it and it literally takes like less than 3 minutes to make. Pic related, it's the final product which I'm eating right now. Obviously it's missing a lot of ingredients that you'd get at a restaurant, but you can just buy those separately and mix them in. Hope this helps someone feel better!
